commitResults.messageTitle: [#747] SystemTest: Delete ft_temp folder after test (#973)
commitResults.messageBody:
ft_temp folder is generated after running system test.

This folder is unnecessary to stay in our repo directory and may 
confuse code navigation.

Let's add a cleanup method to delete the folder after the system 
test.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#940] ReportGenerator#generateReposReport: SLAP copying of template file (#977)
commitResults.messageBody:
The operation to copy template file before cloning and analyzing the
repositories in ReportGenerator#generateReposReport is specified at 
a granular level.

It clashes with the higher level of abstraction used for the other
operations in ReportGenerator#generateReposReport.

Let's abstract out the copying of template files into a separate 
method and then call this method from 
ReportGenerator#generateReposReport.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1044] Update date hashes on reset date range (#1068)
commitResults.messageBody:
Resetting the date range would occasionally not change the date 
hashes in the URL, causing a refresh of the page to load the 
outdated filter date range. 

This bug occurs when until or since date is not specified on
generating the report.

Let's make sure that the date hashes gets updated all the time.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#850] Ignore git submodules when analyzing repos (#1127)
commitResults.messageBody:
Repos that contains git submodules are not handled properly and cannot
be analyzed.

This is due to the diff result including the submodule information.

Let set `--ignore-submodules=all` in the git diff command to ignore all
submodule information.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1083] RepoConfiguration: remove `annotationOverwrite` flag  (#1117)
commitResults.messageBody:
There is an `annotationOverwrite` flag in the `RepoConfiguration`. 
The flag is redundant because it defaults to `true` and is never 
utilized in the main code.

Since there is currently no planned use case, for better code 
quality, we should remove the unnecessary code.

Let's remove this flag from the `RepoConfiguration`.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1021]: Use BASE_URL constant instead of string  (#1033)
commitResults.messageBody:
There are multiple occurrences of the same string 
'https://github.com' in the frontend.

Let's replace the string with a constant 'BASE_URL' in the files.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1046] v_summary: refactor duplicate code (#1056)
commitResults.messageBody:
There is an instance of code duplication in 'v_summary.js'. 
Specifically, the definition of a function that is passed to the 
comparator has been duplicated in the case of grouping by repos and 
by authors.

Let's extract this duplicated portion of code into a helper function 
so that it may be referenced by the comparator.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#806, #951] ReportGenerator: return paths of generated files (#939)
commitResults.messageBody:
The method `ReportGenerator#generateReposReport` returns a list of
paths to the JSON files that need to be zipped. 

However, the list is made up by the file paths of expected output and
not the file paths of actual generated files. As a good practice, and
also to ensure that only the correct files are zipped, the latter is
preferred. 

Let's return a Optional<Path> from `FileUtil#writeJsonFile` so that
callers of this method can determine whether a JSON file was
successfully generated.

This allows `generateReposReport` to only return paths to JSON files
that were successfully generated.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#871, #952] CSV files: ignore blank lines before the header (#903)
commitResults.messageBody:
CsvParser treats the first non-empty line as the header row.

When a CSV file contains blank line(s) above the header, the blank line
would be taken as the header, causing the subsequent rows in the CSV
file to be flagged as malformed. Hence, any CSV file with blank lines
before the header will be parsed incorrectly. 

Let's modify CsvParser such that it skips all the blank lines preceding
the header, and picks the first non blank line as the header.

The Apache Commons CSV library currently does not provide any methods
to skip blank lines preceding the header. This limitation is documented
in:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CSV-127 

Hence, let's implement a custom line-skipping behavior using a
BufferedReader.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#934] CsvParser: Remove extra comma in warning logs (#935)
commitResults.messageBody:
When a line in a CSV config is found to be malformed, the logger prints 
the contents of the line in a warning message. The current method causes
an extra comma to be printed.

This extra comma may make debugging more confusing.

Let's modify the method used to extract the contents of a line, such 
that there are no extra commas.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#736] CLI: allow "--ignore-standalone-config" flag to override CSV values (#928)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense ignores the --ignore-standalone-config command line flag when
parsing a repo-config csv file.

We can allow the --ignore-standalone-config command line flag to
override all entries in the "Ignore Standalone Config" column of
repo-config.csv. This provides users with an easy method of setting
this flag for all repos, without having to edit each line of the csv.

To achieve this, let's move the isStandaloneConfigIgnored attribute
from the LocationsCliArguments class, to its superclass: CliArguments.
This will allow us to access the --ignore-standalone-config flag's
value when parsing RepoConfigurations from both LocationsCliArguments
and ConfigCliArguments.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#872] CsvParser: improve exception handling when a csv file has incorrect number of columns in header (#955)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense crashes abruptly when any of the CSV config files do not 
have the expected number of columns in their headers.

We should catch this error early and provide the user with a clearer
error message.

Let's add a header validation step to the CSV parsing process. This 
step will verify if the CSV file's header has the right number of 
columns.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1001] CSS: Increase z-index for center divider div (#1011)
commitResults.messageBody:
When we scroll horizontally in the Code Panel, the code snippets and 
code toggle buttons overlap with the center divider.

Let's fix this bug by increasing the z-index of the #tab-resize div, and 
the div that closes the right tab. We can use a value of 100, since the 
z-index of #tab-resize-guide div is already set to 100. For better 
scalability, let's also use a SASS map to store these z-index values.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1032] Author: fix error in copy constructor (#1036)
commitResults.messageBody:
The Author class has a constructor that accepts an existing Author
object and creates a copy. 

However, the constructor assigns the list of author aliases of the 
copied instance to the `ignoreGlobList` attribute of the new 
instance.

Let's fix this error so methods that use this constructor will not
face erroneous behavior.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#942] CsvParser: Improve exception handling when csv config has no valid recods (#916)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense crashes with an unhelpful error message if the repo-config
csv has zero valid records.

If the repo-config csv has no valid records, we should provide a
clear warning to the user and then terminate execution. In the case 
of optional csv files, we should provide a warning and then continue 
execution.

Let's 
- implement this behaviour by explicity checking the number of valid
  records found by CsvParser. 
- throw an InvalidCsvException if there are no valid records in a 
  csv file.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1022] FileInfoAnalyzer: Deprecate "//@reused" tag (#1039)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense will not include a file in the authorship analysis if the 
first line of the file contains the `//@reused` string.

This feature is not being used.

Let's remove this feature to simplify the codebase.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1076] Author: add a `isIgnoringFile` method (#1085)
commitResults.messageBody:
There are a few instances where we obtain the `ignoreGlobMatcher` 
from an Author instance first to manually check if this matches with 
a given file path.

Let's allow the Author instance to tell clients if it is ignoring a 
particular file (given a filepath) - instead of giving clients the
ignoreGlobMatcher and letting clients figure out the answer on their 
own.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1060] Report: record time taken for report generation in hidden element (#1066)
commitResults.messageBody:
It is sometimes not possible / inconvenient to retrieve the 
RepoSense log output, if we want to view the time taken for 
generating a report.

Let's record the time taken for report generation, as a hidden
element in the report as well as a field in the summary.json file.
This will allow developers to find out the amount of time taken
in generating the report.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#823, #981] AnnotatorAnalyzer: Fix code disowning mechanism (#1067)
commitResults.messageBody:
Suppose that `random-user` is not the git author name of any author
in a git repository(i.e. it is just a placeholder name). RepoSense 
does not correctly mark code as disowned when a user marks a code 
block with the `@@author random-user` tag. Only the line containing 
the `@@author random-user` tag is treated as disowned, while the 
remaining code block is still attributed to the author deduced from 
the git blame analysis.

This bug occurs because the code in AnnotatorAnalyzer uses a 
constant UNKNOWN_AUTHOR to represent both the case where there is no 
currently active annotation override AND the case where the user has 
used a "@@author random-user" tag.

Let's use Optionals to store the author names obtained from the
`@@author` tags, so we can identify the case where the user has used
a `@@author random-user` tag.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#931] Code view: Default sorting in descending order (#932)
commitResults.messageBody:
In Code view, the default order for LoC is ascending.

Let's make the default order descending as it is more meaningful to
have bigger changes on top as they should be more interesting.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#352] User Guide: add quick start guide to use RepoSense with Netlify (#924)
commitResults.messageBody:
Users would need to download .jar file to run RepoSense.

Let's add a quick start section to User Guide to instruct users to 
use RepoSense through Netlify so they can get started without 
downloading any files. This should ease users into using RepoSense.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#947] Synchronising different tab views (#948)
commitResults.messageBody:
It's difficult to distinguish between the authorship and zoom views as 
there are no obvious symbols to identify which is which. 

Let's add a header to both the views for easy identification and a link 
to the zoom title to make it more consistent with authorship.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#960]Refactor Authorship Css (#986)
commitResults.messageBody:
The JS/HTML code of each component has already rested in its own 
file, but all the CSS are still in one file. 

Let's refactor the Authorship CSS into a new file for better 
scalability and readability.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#960] Refactor Summary CSS (#1003)
commitResults.messageBody:
The JS/HTML code of each component has already rested in its own 
file, but all the CSS are still in one file. 

Let's refactor the Summary CSS into a new file for better scalability 
and readability.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#964] Add UG link to report page (#983)
commitResults.messageBody:
The link to the UG in the documents points to the released version of 
the UG. As a result, there may be some discrepancies between the master 
and the release branch.

Let's add a link to the UG on the report page corresponding to the 
version that RepoSense was ran on.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#873, #1016, #1049]Enable octocat icon for merge group (#1017)
commitResults.messageBody:
There are not a lot of features that the user can use when merge 
group is active. 

Let's 
  - add the octocat icon to enhance the usage of merge group. 
  - fix the thickness of contribution bars by changing rem to pix.

When it's `group by Repo`, the octocat icon will link to the group's
repository. When it's `group by Author`, the octocat icon will link 
to the author's github profile.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#960] Refactor Ramp CSS (#1055)
commitResults.messageBody:
The JS/HTML code of each component has already rested in its own 
file, but all the CSS are still in one file. 

Let's refactor the Ramp CSS into a new file for better scalability 
and readability.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#522] Implement style checker on .pug files (#987)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense has CheckStyle, ESLint and Stylelint to check our java, 
javascript and css code styles automatically. However, `.pug` files 
are not covered by any of these tools.

Let's implement pug-lint to check the code styles of .pug files.

TODO: Add a line wrap rule in the future

commitResults.messageTitle: [#906, #994, #1006] UserGuide: update doc and remove errors (#907)
commitResults.messageBody:
With the recently added group-config.csv file, the new changes 
possible in the local configuration are not reflected in the
documentation.

Users can configure their csv files to analyse multiple repos in 
their own custom way, but they may be confused about how to do so as 
the user guide is outdated. 

Let's update the user guide to reflect the changes possible through
group-config.csv in the local configuration to analyse multiple 
repos. Let's also fix the errors in the Tool Bar section and fix the 
formatting of repo-config.csv example.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#947] Authorship view: update sort controls (#1074)
commitResults.messageBody:
The sort controls in the Authorship view are a value updated by
watched property. 

This is not as efficient as a computed property. 

Let's make the sort controls in Authorship view a computed property. 
This will also help in making the code across different views 
consistent.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#960] Refactor Zoom CSS (#1079)
commitResults.messageBody:
The JS/HTML code of each component has already rested in its own 
file, but all the CSS are still in one file. 

Let's refactor the Zoom CSS into a new file for better scalability 
and readability.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1061] build.gradle: remove unused dependency (#1095)
commitResults.messageBody:
There is an unused dependency in the Gradle config.

Let's remove the unused dependencies to reduce the build time.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1004] Make Code Panel consistent with Chart Panel (#1080)
commitResults.messageBody:
The Code Panel and Chart Panel look very different from each other.

Making them be more similar can enhance the user experience.

Let's
- make file title similar to Github's way of displaying
- change background for Code and Commit Panel to white
- change sidebar color to grey

commitResults.messageTitle: [#46] Show total time after batch processing (#758)
commitResults.messageBody:
After running the CLI command, the total time taken to process and 
generate the report is not shown in the console output.

Users might find it useful to keep track of the time taken to 
generate the report.

Let's use the logger to output the total time taken from running the 
CLI command until the report is generated.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#785] ChartView: fix authors with unaccounted lines (#789)
commitResults.messageBody:
The git blame command used in RepoSense contains the option -w, which
ignores whitespace when comparing the parent’s version and the child’s
to find where the lines came from.

When an author did not change the content but only the position of
specific lines of code, the previous author will be recognised as the 
author that changed these lines. If the previous author did not
contribute during the analysis period, his/her ramp chart will be
empty while the contribution bar will be present.

Let's add an extra check in aggregateBlameInfo for lines of code with
the author committed date that is not within the duration of 
specified since date and until date. Those lines of code's author will
be set to unknown, which will resolve the issue above.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#879] Display commit tags in commits panel (#969)
commitResults.messageBody:
The tags of each commit are not shown in the commits panel.

With the active use of git tags in CS21x3 repositories, it is useful to 
provide tutors on the usage and information of tags in each commit.

Let's display the tags of each commit (if there's any) in the commits 
panel.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#984] Fix miscalculation of expanded commit message count (#998)
commitResults.messageBody:
We get the number of expanded commit message count in zoom tab based on
the number of divs with class name 'commit-message active'.

Commit messages without commit message bodies also have default class
name of 'commit-message active', which leads to the expanded commit
message count to not reflect on the true number of commit messages that
are expanded.

Let's append the class name 'message-body' to commit messages that have
commit message bodies, to distinguish between messages that can be
expanded and vice versa.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1029] Contribution Bar: restore the float left property (#1030)
commitResults.messageBody:
Due to the regression of #1003, the css property 'float: left' was left
out in the contribution bar. When break down by file type is checked,
the contribution bar for each file type occupies separate lines
instead of continuous lines.

Let's restore the css property 'float: left' back to the contribution
bar.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1019] Handle commit info extraction for empty commits (#1020)
commitResults.messageBody:
Analyzing repo with empty commits causes CommitInfoAnalyzer to throw 
ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. This occurs in 
CommitInfoExtractor#parseGitLogResults, where info lines and stat 
lines are split based on the last index of the newline character 
`\n`.

As empty commits have no stat lines, it leads to 
ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException due to the use of new line separator.

Let's:
- use '|' character as the splitting point of info lines and stat 
  lines, instead of the new line '\n' character. This will ensure 
  that the ref name details will always be within info lines instead
  of stat lines.
- add a check for the availability of the ref name before accessing 
  it to prevent the exception. 

No stat lines occurs for commits that are empty (done by git commit 
--allow-empty), since no files are changed. The last index of the 
newline character will situate before the ref name details, and info
line will contain all characters before that index while stat line 
contains the ref name details. Since the ref name is no longer in 
the info lines, accessing the REF_NAME_INDEX within the info lines 
will incur an ArrayOutOfBoundsException.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1027] Modify UI for tags (#1028)
commitResults.messageBody:
Some tags split to the next line when the list of tags are too long. 
Tags also appear vertically close together when the list occupies 
more than one line.

Let's change the css property `display` to be `inline-block` and add 
some top and bottom margins to each tag.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#999] Remove empty zoom__day divs (#1000)
commitResults.messageBody:
When granularity is set to week, the 'pushCommitsWeek' method gets 
all possible weeks (week 1, 2, 3, etc...) from start date until the 
end date and pushes it to 'user.commits', no matter the week has any 
commits at all. Additionally, commits with zero insertions but with 
deletions are also not taken into consideration in the commits 
panel.

Weeks that have no commits is not useful and redundant. Commits with
only deletions are maybe useful as it may represent 
refactoring/removing redundant code.

Let's add a check to add a week only if it has commits. And remove 
the check for commits with zero insertions, so that commits with 
only deletions are also included.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1043] Fix bug of incorrect commit dates when merge group (#1045)
commitResults.messageBody:
When merge group is checked, some commits are seen with committed
dates that are incompatible to the real committed dates.

Commits with the same date are appended together in 'mergedCommits'.
Since 'mergedCommits' is being sorted before all the merged commits 
for a particular group is gathered, the order of the 'mergedCommits' 
is changed, and some commits with the same date are appended 
wrongly.

Let's move the sorting of 'mergedCommits' after the all merged 
commits are gathered, this will ensure commits with the same date 
are appended correctly.

The order of the 'mergedCommits' matters, as we use an additional js 
object 'dateToIndexMap' maps dates to the corresponding index in 
'mergedCommits'. Once the order has changed, the 'dateToIndexMap' no 
longer contains the accurate mappings and hence, commits are 
appended wrongly.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add commit message length configuration border (#1048)
commitResults.messageBody:
GitHub's maximum length of commit message's subject line and body is 
defaulted at 50 and 72 characters respectively.

Commits panel does not show the indication of the maximum lengths.

Let's add a dotted lines for commit message bodies at 72 characters 
and subject lines at 50 characters, these lines indicate whether a 
commit message's subject line or body exceed GitHub's maximum 
length.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1005, #1010] Code Panel: match font with GitHub and break lines when overflow (#1008)
commitResults.messageBody:
When the file path or lines of code overflows, it takes up a large 
amount of empty space in order to accomodate to it's length. The 
font size of the code and file path is also rather big and takes up 
much space.

Let's set the file path and lines of code to break into next lines 
when it overflows. Also, let's set the font-family and font-size of 
the code to match with GitHub.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1109] Config.json: include active author and pug file format (#1123)
commitResults.messageBody:
The default configuration consists of authors that are no longer
active in committing code to RepoSense. The jade file format is
no longer used in RepoSense as it is replaced by pug file format.

Let's 
- add a recent active author, as it may reveal potential bugs
- replace jade to pug file format

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1140] Update date hashes when updating date range (#1141)
commitResults.messageBody:
Clicking on the `show ramp chart in this period` button does not update 
the `since` and `until` date hashes, which leads to a different summary 
period after reloading the page.

This is due to the `hasModifedSinceDate` and `hasModifiedUntilDate` not
set to true when calling `updateDateRange`, which prevents the since and 
until date hashes to be updated.

Let's set `hasModifedSinceDate` and `hasModifiedUntilDate` to be true 
when updateDateRange is called.

commitResults.messageTitle: v_summary: refactor the structure of summary-charts__title (#1106)
commitResults.messageBody:
The `summary-charts__title` div is separated in two, each for when
`filterGroupSelection` is `groupByRepos` and `groupByAuthors` 
respectively.

There is overlapping in code among the two, and adding a new 
common component in `summary-charts__title` needs to be done twice, 
which is redundant.

Let's refactor the structure `summary-charts__title` div to share 
the common divs/components.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#950] Use Surge as alternative for Netlify (#1165)
commitResults.messageBody:
Netlify's build quota is not enough for RepoSense's build usage.

Let's deploy on Surge instead, using Travis to run the build and 
provide a Github Status on each PR that links users to the deployed 
Surge site.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1167] Revert PR #967 while keeping zoom tab independent of summary (#1172)
commitResults.messageBody:
PR #967 causes multiple bugs in zoom tab and authorship tab, due to
some data value inside the side panels are not re-rendered when prop 
`info` changes.

Fixing these bugs may delay our upcoming release, so reverting the 
changes that lead to these bugs may be the best option.

Let's revert that PR while only keeping the changes to make the zoom 
tab to be independent of summary.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#865] AuthorConfig: further improve the branch field (#878)
commitResults.messageBody:
In the author-config.csv, branch is an optional field that will
automatically uses the default branch in the repo field.

However, this can be improved such that if the branch field is not
filled, we can bind that AuthorConfig to all the RepoConfig that has the
same repo's location irregardless of branch. This can help users to
easily setup config files to analyse multiple branches of a repo.

Let's bind the AuthorConfig to all the RepoConfig that has the same
repo's location irregardless of branch if the branch field is not
filled.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#900] group-config.csv: make location optional (#914)
commitResults.messageBody:
In the group-config.csv, location is a compulsory field that only has one
value.  Specifying groups for all repos requires the user to manually key
in groups for each repo.

However, this can be improved such that if the location field is not
filled, we can bind that GroupConfig to all the RepoConfig. This can
help the user save the time listing all the possible combinations of
repos and groups when they want to specify groups for all repos.

Let's bind the GroupConfig to all the RepoConfig if the location
field is not filled.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#980] URL: date adapted without validation (#990)
commitResults.messageBody:
Date in authorship can be modified using URL. However, a date range will 
still be adapted even if it is invalid.

This can be fixed by adding extra validation function for window hash.

Let's put a validation for the date parameters in the URL.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1009] AppVeyor Failing: remove outdated tests (#1015)
commitResults.messageBody:
AppVeyor CI is failing in all PRs as it has updated its worker 
image, which uses Git 2.25 instead of Git 2.23.

From Git v2.24, Git for windows would print error for an illegal
file name and prevent it from adding into the index. As in our test 
cases we run the command `git checkout someInvalidName`, an 
exception is expected to be thrown, and since we do not catch it, 
the tests fail. 

Let's remove the 2 outdated test as the git command now handles
detection of invalid filename and will throw exception at the very
beginning.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#885] Allow reset search filter (#895)
commitResults.messageBody:
The user has to manually delete the keywords and press another enter 
to go back to the full view.

However, this can be improved by providing a reset button to clear 
the search bar, which can help the user save time for deleting. 

Let's provide a button to reset the search bar.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#988] Ramp chart: inconsistency in the length of contribution line (#991)
commitResults.messageBody:
Toggling the `breakdown by filetype` checkbox changes the length of the
contribution bar even though the LoC remains constant.

This occurs due to the inaccurate data in json file. The
authorFileTypeContributionMap in commit.json have multiple entries of the 
same key. In the frontend, the last entry would be taken instead of all 
of the entries provided. This results in the wrong calculation of the total 
contribution of each file type.

Let's override FileType#hashCode to correctly update the LoC number 
instead of creating a new entry.

In the backend, we use AuthorshipSummary#addAuthorContributionCount
to increment line number and we consider FileType (the key) and
LoC (the value) as an entry in the HashMap. The HashMap is then output
to the commit.json file as authorFileTypeContributionMap. However, the 
default HashCode will digest all data stored in FileType, other data 
like path and pathsGlob is also taken into consideration when comparing 
the key to update the entry. So, instead of updating, a new entry will 
be created. Thus in AuthorshipSummary#authorFileTypeContributionMap, 
each author can have multiple entry with same FileType#label. And the 
resulted authorFileTypeContributionMap in json file will have multiple 
entry of the same key.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#920] Ramp chart: show percentile for each item (#922)
commitResults.messageBody:
We have index number for each group in the ramp chart but not its
percentile. It is hard to tell the ranking position of the group.

This can be improved to show the percentile of each item so that it
is easy to see whether an item is in the 20%th percentile and so on.

Let's add a percentile number at the right side of each group.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#838] ZoomTab: add sort controls  (#943)
commitResults.messageBody:
We have Zoom tab shows the list of commits in the order from
earliest to latest commits (without an option to reverse the sorting
order or change the sorting type).

This can be improved by allowing the user to view the commits in
reverse chronological order and add other sorting options such as
LOC.

Let's add a sorting field to allow the user to sort the commits
according to Loc or time, and also allow the commits to be
displayed in reverse order.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1031] Commits panel: ramp appears outside row (#1034)
commitResults.messageBody:
The ramp slice in Commits panel may appear outside of the blue 
rectangle.

We should crop the ramp slice if it appears outside of the row, like
what we did for the Chart panel.

Let's set the overflow property to be hidden for the ramp div.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1023] Authorship Panel: expand all button always appear when first open the page (#1040)
commitResults.messageBody:
The `expand all` button will always appear on the authorship panel 
when we first open the page or when refresh the page, until the
loading is complete. The button to display is supposed to be
`collapse all` as we are to display all the file details initially.

Let's display the `collapse all` button at the very beginning, and 
update all relevant checkboxes, radio buttons using proper Vue 
model.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1071] Zoom view: provide a way to highlight the commit (#1075)
commitResults.messageBody:
Clicking a tag jumps to a list of commits full of tags. Users may
not be able to find the commit with that tag easily.

We can highlight the resulting commit with that particular tag by 
providing a light blue border around the message div.

Let's add a focus property to the commit message body.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#576] Refactor summary from index (#1062)
commitResults.messageBody:
The entire v_summary template resides in the index pug file.

Let's refactor v_summary to move it into its own component so that 
RepoSense's dashboard is much more extendable in the future.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#892] Ramp chart: allow filtering by file type/group (#1025)
commitResults.messageBody:
We have code view can be filtered by file type/group but ramp chart in 
Chart Panel cannot be filtered and sorted like that.

This can be improved by only display selected portion of contribution
bar corresponding to selected file type. Also, if the user choose to 
sort by contribution, only the file types in selected ones will be 
considered.

Let's add a set of file type check boxes in Chart panel and only display
and sort according to selected file types.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#1124] Authorship: file name starting with period not displayed (#1125)
commitResults.messageBody:
File with name starting with period will not have its detail 
displayed on authorship panel.

This is due to the minimatch library used which by default will not
match name `a/**/b` with `a/.d/b`, unless dot is set. So the file is
filtered out from selected files.

Let's set the dot property to true to allow the file details to be
displayed properly.

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix additional upward movement on expanding code (#966)
commitResults.messageBody:
Clicking the expand button may cause the code to move up a bit 
before expanding. This occurs more frequently when the number of 
code lines to load is large, or the client is slow. 

This is due to asynchronous data loading by Vue, causing observable 
CSS updates to the code block before the code has been loaded into 
the DOM.

Let's execute the CSS change for the code block only after the 
segment's code lines have been loaded.
